**G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to **G.L. c. 212, § 4**, which grants the Superior Court jurisdiction over civil actions where the damages claimed exceed $50,000, and over tort actions generally.

**G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1**.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under **G.L. c. 223, § 1**, because the cause of action arose in Middlesex County, Massachusetts.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 708.proposition: Under **Massachusetts common law**, a store owner owes business invitees a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 708.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard abolished the strict common-law invitee/licensee distinction in Massachusetts and adopted a general duty of reasonable care owed by possessors of land to lawful visitors, which includes business customers of a store. While the provided excerpt is from a concurrence and focuses on trespassers, the main opinion at 363 Mass. 707–08 explains that occupiers must exercise reasonable care to keep the premises reasonably safe for lawful visitors, which covers business invitees such as store customers. Thus, the case supports the proposition, though it reframes it in broader terms.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 708.relevant_excerpt: We hold, therefore, that the common law distinctions between invitees and licensees should be abolished. The standard of care owed by an occupier of land should no longer depend on the status of the entrant but on whether the occupier has exercised reasonable care in the circumstances to maintain his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.

*Wilbur v. Newton*, 302 Mass. 38, 39 (19.proposition: Under **Massachusetts common law**, a store owner owes business invitees a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition.
*Wilbur v. Newton*, 302 Mass. 38, 39 (19.support_reasoning: This decision is a zoning/land-use case about the validity of a city's zoning ordinance and the regulation of a sand and gravel operation. It does not involve a store, a business invitee, premises liability, or any discussion of the duty of care owed by a possessor of land to invitees. Therefore it does not provide authority for the claimed Massachusetts common-law duty of a store owner toward business invitees.
*Wilbur v. Newton*, 302 Mass. 38, 39 (19.relevant_excerpt: On this branch of the case the precise issue is whether it was, or is, so unreasonable and arbitrary to prohibit new buildings, other than residences, on or near the gravel bearing portions of the Wilbur and Esty lands as clearly to place such prohibition beyond the scope of legislative competency.

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: This duty includes maintaining display shelves and merchandise in a condition that does not pose an unreasonable risk of harm to patrons.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion is entirely about premises liability for snow and ice accumulations in parking lots and walkways. It discusses the general duty of reasonable care to maintain property in a reasonably safe condition, but it does not address duties specific to maintaining display shelves or merchandise, nor any indoor store fixture conditions. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for a proposition about duties regarding display shelves and merchandise.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, … the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 166.raw_text: *Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 166 (1980) (negligence found where property owner failed to remedy or warn of known hazards)
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 166.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by allowing heavy boxes to be stacked unsafely without restraints, by failing to inspect the shelving for hazards, and by failing to institute reasonable precautions against foreseeable harm.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 166.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a defendant’s breach of duty by unsafe stacking of boxes, failure to inspect shelving, and failure to take precautions against foreseeable harm—essentially a premises-liability/negligent-storage fact pattern. Young v. Garwacki addresses a landlord’s duty in negligence to maintain rental premises (here, a defective porch railing) and abolishes certain landlord-tenant status-based limitations. While it supports the general idea that a landlord may be negligent for failing to remedy or warn of known hazards, it does not involve shelving, inspections of stacked items, or the specific duty described, so it is too factually distinct to be accurate authority for that particular proposition.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 166.relevant_excerpt: “In December, 1976, the landlord’s insurance company had informed him that the railing was dangerous and had cancelled his liability insurance. At that time, the landlord warned the tenant of the danger and bought materials to repair the railing, but he made no repairs. … [T]he jury found that the landlord did not exercise reasonable care in his maintenance of the premises, that his negligence was the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries…”

See *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146.raw_text: See *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006) (proximate cause established where harm is foreseeable consequence of negligent act)
See *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries and damages.
See *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146.support_reasoning: The case focuses on duty and foreseeability, and explicitly separates duty from the causation questions, which it identifies as matters for the jury. It does not hold that defendant’s negligence was in fact the direct and proximate cause of the officer’s injuries; instead, it only finds a duty of reasonable care and reverses summary judgment so a jury can decide breach and causation. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition that the defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries.
See *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146.relevant_excerpt: "To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. ... We generally consider the latter three questions ... to be the special province of the jury. ... However, the existence of a duty is a question of law, and is thus an appropriate subject of summary judgment."

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85**.proposition: Plaintiff’s losses, including medical expenses, lost wages, and non‑economic damages, are compensable under **Massachusetts common law of negligence** and **G.L. c. 231, § 85**, which governs comparative negligence and allocation of fault.

*Stepakoff v. Kantar*, 393 Mass. 836, 84.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes a failure to exercise the degree of care that a reasonably prudent retailer would exercise under similar circumstances.
*Stepakoff v. Kantar*, 393 Mass. 836, 84.support_reasoning: The case concerns a psychiatrist’s malpractice duty to a suicidal patient, not the duty of a retailer. The court expressly defines negligence for a physician-specialist in terms of conformity with the standard of care of the average qualified psychiatrist, and it rejects a separate, generalized ‘reasonableness’ duty in that context. It therefore does not establish or affirm any legal principle about the standard of care owed by a reasonably prudent retailer under similar circumstances.
*Stepakoff v. Kantar*, 393 Mass. 836, 84.relevant_excerpt: “Negligence of a physician who practices a specialty consists of a failure to exercise the degree of care and skill of the average qualified physician practicing that specialty… The rule with respect to the physician-patient relationship is an adaption of the broader negligence principle. In the context of that relationship, the law views the care and skill commonly exercised by the average qualified physician as the equivalent of the ‘care, vigilance and forethought which… the person of ordinary caution and prudence ought to exercise under the particular circumstances.’”

See *Payne v. Wal\u2011Mart Stores, Inc..raw_text: See *Payne v. Wal‑Mart Stores, Inc.*, 965 F. Supp. 2d 307, 310 (D. Mass. 2013)
See *Payne v. Wal\u2011Mart Stores, Inc..proposition: A business owner is liable when injury results from negligently maintained or arranged merchandise on its premises.
See *Payne v. Wal\u2011Mart Stores, Inc..support_reasoning: The provided opinion is an employment discrimination and retaliation case involving a hostile work environment claim. It does not concern premises liability, customer injuries, or negligence in maintaining or arranging merchandise on business premises. Because the case neither discusses nor establishes any rule about a business owner’s liability for negligently maintained or arranged merchandise, it does not support the cited proposition.

*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84, 88.proposition: A business owner is liable when injury results from negligently maintained or arranged merchandise on its premises.
*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84, 88.support_reasoning: The case concerns a landowner’s liability for an allegedly negligently maintained freight elevator, not merchandise or goods arranged for sale. The court discusses the general duty to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition and ultimately finds no negligence under those facts. It neither addresses nor establishes any rule about liability for negligently maintained or arranged merchandise on business premises, so it does not support the specific proposition stated.
*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84, 88.relevant_excerpt: “Clearly, the law imposed on this defendant a duty to maintain his property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … The question to be decided, then, is whether the jury reasonably could have concluded that, in view of all the circumstances, an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have taken steps, not taken by the defendant, to prevent the accident that occurred.”

*Boothby v. Texon, Inc.*, 414 Mass. 468,.proposition: The foreseeable danger of stacked goods falling from a shelf establishes a breach of reasonable care.
*Boothby v. Texon, Inc.*, 414 Mass. 468,.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns an employment contract dispute over alleged permanent employment; it does not involve premises liability, stacked goods, falling objects, or the standard of reasonable care for such physical dangers. The court’s analysis is about contract formation, authority, termination for just cause, damages, and related tortious interference—not about negligence for foreseeable danger from stacked goods. Therefore, it does not support the cited proposition.
*Boothby v. Texon, Inc.*, 414 Mass. 468,.relevant_excerpt: The case contains no discussion of stacked goods, shelves, falling objects, or premises liability. The issues addressed are summarized as follows: “The case proceeded to a second trial on a count for breach of express contract only. … Texon appeals from the denials of motions for judgment notwithstanding the verdict and for new trials… [concerning] the existence of an enforceable contract for permanent employment,” Texon’s right to terminate for unsatisfactory performance, availability of work, and damages.

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 640 (1996)
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries and damages were reasonably foreseeable and directly resulted from Defendant’s negligence.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The quoted concurring opinion expressly agrees with the court that the facts do *not* warrant a finding that the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence. That directly contradicts the claimed proposition that the injuries were reasonably foreseeable and directly resulted from the defendant’s negligence. Thus, this case is authority against, not for, the stated proposition.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff[’]s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641."

**G.L. c. 93A, \u00a7 2**.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 93A, § 2**, while not asserted as an independent count herein, Defendant’s negligent conduct also constitutes an unfair or deceptive act in commerce to the extent it disregards consumers’ safety obligations.

*Alegria v. Payonk*, 101 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to compensation for medical expenses, lost earnings, pain and suffering, and all other damages allowed under **Massachusetts tort law**.
*Alegria v. Payonk*, 101 Mass. App. Ct..case_name: TOCCI BUILDING CORPORATION v. IRIV PARTNERS, LLC, & another (and a companion case ).
*Alegria v. Payonk*, 101 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion in Tocci Building Corp. v. IRIV Partners, LLC concerns interpretation and application of Massachusetts’ Prompt Payment Act in a construction contract dispute. It does not involve personal injury, tort damages, or any discussion of the categories of damages (medical expenses, lost earnings, pain and suffering, etc.) recoverable under Massachusetts tort law. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition about a plaintiff’s entitlement to tort damages.
*Alegria v. Payonk*, 101 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: This case requires us to construe for the first time the provisions of the Prompt Payment Act, G. L. c. 149, § 29E (the act or statute). That statute applies to certain private contracts for construction with respect to projects for the erection, alteration, repair, or removal of buildings or structures, or for other improvement to real property... Designed to ensure the prompt payment of, or resolution of disputes about, invoices for periodic payment made by contractors during the course of work on such projects, the act provides...

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B**.proposition: Award Plaintiff compensatory damages in an amount to be determined at trial, but reasonably believed to exceed $50,000, including: ... Pre‑ and post‑judgment interest as permitted under **G.L. c. 231, § 6B**;
